Situation1: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Their teacher invited them to summarize key teachings for a temple session tomorrow.
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, the hum of the refrigerator barely masking the chatter from the pharmacy counter. My phone buzzed with a new pharmacy newsletter—another reminder to keep up with the latest medications and treatment guidelines. I scrolled through the updates, trying to absorb the essentials about a new anticoagulant, but my mind kept drifting. My Buddhist teacher had asked me to summarize key teachings for tomorrow’s temple session, a responsibility I cherished. I should be reading the sutras, reflecting on impermanence and compassion, but instead, I was parsing clinical trial data and side effect profiles. The expectation to be a competent, up-to-date pharmacist pressed on me, but so did the call to deepen my spiritual understanding and serve my sangha. I felt torn, my attention split, guilt rising no matter which task I chose. The clock ticked down my break, and I stared at my phone, paralyzed between two worlds, unsure which path to follow in this moment.
